11661862-DS-23: MEDICINE Allergies: Accupril / gemfibrozil / Statins-Hmg-Coa Reductase Inhibitors / metformin Attending: Chief Complaint: confusion, fever, shortness of breath Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: PICC placement () History of Present Illness: male with history of asthma, type 2 diabetes, CAD s/p CABG , afib on apixaban, hypertension, and prostate cancer who presented with acute onset shortness of breath and altered mental status. Prior to this he had been having difficulty urinating. His wife called EMS night because the patient was having difficulty breathing. He was found in moderate respiratory distress and placed on BiPAP with improvement. O2 sat has been above 90%. Received nebs and steroids with EMS. Patient had been more somnolent than usual since his shortness of breath started. His wife does not think he has had fevers at home. Initial history was limited due to the patient's somnolence; he is also hard of hearing. He did awaken to voice. He denied chest pain or abdominal pain. In the ED, initial vitals: Yest 22:00 0 104.8 93 118/54 24 100% bipap Exam notable for: somnolent but arousable to voice on arrival, full neck range of motion. Labs notable for: WBC 6.8 (93% PMN), Hgb 10.1 (baseline appears , Na 128 (recent values in 140s), Cr 1.5 (baseline creatinine about 1.0), glucose 144, INR 1.7, AST 46, LFTs otherwise normal, VBG lactate 3.1, trop negative x1, BNP 594, flu negative, UA with mild hematuria Imaging notable for: -CT head negative -CT chest with no PNA, no PE, mild atelectasis -CXR with vascular congestion Pt given: 2g IV cefepime (10pm), 1500 IV vanco (11pm), 1g PR APAP (10pm), 1L total LR On reevaluation, patient was more awake and alert, able to recount his history and symptoms (with some difficulty giving his difficulty hearing). Weaned from BiPAP to NC. His only complaint was that he was having difficulty urinating earlier. He does have an enlarged prostate. Foley was placed. No headache, neck pain, meningismus. ED did not feel LP was warranted. Vitals prior to transfer: Today 01:50 0 99.8 75 113/62 19 96% 2L NC Upon arrival to the floor, the patient is not able to interact. His wife confirmed the above and added he was unsteady coming out of bed today, fell and did not strike head. He normally uses a walker when outside the house but was not using at the time. He is normally A&Ox3, occasionally forgets minor things but is able to converse and interact normally. Had been usual self (no confusion, excess sleeping, etc.) until a few hours before EMS called. Since symptoms started he has been hesitating before speaking. When alert today he has been moving all limbs. Had no chest pain, abdominal symptoms, bloody stool, rash. Last BM a few days ago. No recent hospitalizations since CABG last year, saw PCP and within last few months. Per wife, med list from most recent PCP visit should be correct. Does not have list with patient. Brief Hospital Course: ASSESSMENT & PLAN: male with history of asthma, type 2 diabetes, CAD s/p CABG , afib on apixaban, hypertension, and prostate cancer (on lupron) who was admitted with somnolence and dyspnea, found to have high fever and hyponatremia w/ . Pt was empirically treated with abx, found to have strep mitis/oralis bacteremia with unclear source. Was narrowed to CTX and discharged with PICC for 4 weeks of treatment. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: [ ] Continue CTX 2g q24h through (for 4 week course) [ ] Will need weekly CBC w/ diff, BUN, Cr, AST/ALT/TBili/ALP, CRP (per ID) ALL LAB RESULTS SHOULD BE SENT TO: ATTN: CLINIC FAX: [ ] Last day of antibiotics is [ ] Should be seen by dentistry in the setting of Strep viridans bacteremia w/ unclear source ACUTE ISSUES: # Fever # Strep mitis/oralis bacteremia Pt presented with AMS and fever to 104.8. Was empirically started on vanc/cefepime with subsequent improvement. TTE without vegetations; TEE and LP deferred per ID team. Blood cx grew Strep mitis/oralis. Was narrowed to CTX. Urine cx growing alpha hemolytic colonies; likely spillover from blood per ID. MRSA swab negative. Given severe initial presentation, it was decided by ID to treat empirically with 4 week course. PICC was placed and pt was discharged on CTX 2g q24h for 4 week course, set to end on . Pt has planned follow-up with outpt ID and will undergo weekly labs per their team. # Encephalopathy Pt presented with AMS and difficulty breathing, found to be febrile to 104.8 with labs notable for Na 128. CT head negative for stroke or bleed, is on anticoagulation, and had no significant afib burden on recent ziopatch. No inciting med changes. Encephalopathy likely multifactorial, with infection as major source (being treated w/ abx), as well as hyponatremia (resolved). Largely resolved after 24 hours of abx. No other clear source of AMS on work-up; TSH, B12, RPR, AM cortisol all wnl. Per wife, pt was back to baseline prior to discharge with plan to continue abx for 4 weeks as above. # Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure # Asthma Pt presented with SOB and hypoxia. Thought to be multifactorial from worsened mental status, mild volume overload, and asthma. CTA negative for PE. No signs of COPD or significant pulm edema on CXR. Mild end-exp wheezes on exdam. Pt was continued on his home albuterol and Advair. He was diuresed with IV Lasix boluses. Was also given duonebs with improvement. Resumed home montelukast. # Acute on Chronic HFpEF # Volume Overload Pt has significant hx of CAD s/p 5vCABG. On lasix 40mg PO at home. Diuretics initially held i/s/o on admission. Found to be volume overloaded on exam. Diuresed with IV lasix after resolved. Discharged on home Lasix. # Hyponatremia # Presented with Na 128 and Cr 1.5 (from baseline at 1). Urine Na <20. Given 1L LR total in the ED. Improved Na to 141 and Cr to 1.2. Thought to be prerenal in setting of infection. Less c/f CHF, though volume overloaded on exam. continued to improve and resolved prior to discharge. Pt was diuresed with IV Lasix later in course and was discharged on his home Lasix. # LFT Abnormalities LFTs were normal on admission. However, incr to ALT 68, AST 231, nl Alk Phos and TBili.after initiation of abx with hepatocellular pattern of injury. Likely drug-induced I/s/o high dose abx therapy. Activity Status: Ambulatory Independent. Discharge Instructions: Dear Mr. , It was a pleasure taking part in your care here at ! Why was I admitted to the hospital? You were admitted for confusion and difficulty breathing, and were found to have bacteria in your blood. What was done for me while I was in the hospital? You were given antibiotics to treat your infection. You were given a special IV to help you get the rest of your treatment at home. What should I do when I leave the hospital? -Please go to your follow up appointments as scheduled in the discharge papers. Please monitor for new/or worsening symptoms. If you do not feel like you are getting better or have any other concerns, please call your doctor to discuss or return to the emergency room. Sincerely, Your Care Team Followup Instructions:
